author: Fabio Vedovelli

children.text: Aside from a few conventions you have to follow, Remix won‚Äôt stay in your way in terms of project organization. That‚Äôs nice but, at the same time, a double-sided knife.

If you are experienced building server-side applications with Node.js, you‚Äôre probable used to structure your project, and maybe you even have an excellent organization method in place. We suggest you keep your organization and fit Remix within it.
Remix conventions
Remix is small.
Tiny and powerful, but within its boundaries it is indeed opinionated. Here is a list of conventions Remix expects you to follow:
‚Äî You will do all your work in the /app folder, although it is configurable;
‚Äî Everything in the /routes folder will become a route;
‚Äî Folders within the /routes folder
have a special purpose
‚Äî A route file can contain everything, but specially methods (links, loader, action, meta and so on) that allow you to instruct Remix on how to deliver your app;
‚Äî Everything in the /public folder will be web-accessible.
These are the folders Remix deeply care about:

content.code:
Your shinny Remix app/
‚îú‚îÄ app/
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ routes/
‚îú‚îÄ public/

children.text: Keep that in mind and get creative with the rest.
Our project structure

This blog is built with Remix, and we have our project structure in place. We aim to keep our routes as small as possible (an article on the subject will soon be published) and thus we create several files and folders in the app/ directory.
A streamlined version of our organization is:

children.text: Here‚Äôs a breakdown:
routes/blog.index.tsx
: this is the only Remix related file in the whole list
features

: holds the React components directly attached to routes. Moreover, it also contains everything such feature needs to properly do its job: API calls, types, utilities, and components. If a component is related to the feature and only the feature, then it sits in the inner components/ folder.
components
: holds components that are used by the app layout and that are shared among more than one feature. We could expand it further by creating a layouts/ folder in the app/ if that‚Äôs necessary.
styles
: holds any stylesheet ready to be imports in the routes. This folder is git ignored, as the stylesheets are generated on-the-fly by the dev server and the build process.
util
: app-wide utilities not related to a particular feature.
lib
: configuration files for third-party libraries. In this case, the Sanity.io client.
üí° Note that for most of the folders, we have an
index.ts
file, which exports everything from that particular folder. This helps us keep our imports tidy. See below:
Conclusion
If you respect Remix's rules and conventions, which are few, you will be good with your project‚Äôs structure.
A piece of advice
: be strict and mindful with your files and folders. It is uncomfortable and a source of bugs to find yourself lost in your own ‚Äî or lack thereof ‚Äî organization.

title: Does Remix impose a project structure I have to follow?

children.text: Remix brings us back to the olden days of web development by relying on web fundamentals. In practice, this means leaving it to the browser to do the job we‚Äôve grown accustomed to do ourselves.

Form handling is a big part of web development and, while building single page applications, the developer has to keep track of user inputted data, sending it over to the server when it is in a good shape. Typically, data validation occurs while the user is interacting with the form.

But this kind of validation, although good for user experience, is not reliable because a tech-savvy user can find ways to circumvent it. That‚Äôs why a solid application must validate data on the server, primarily. Client-side validation is a plus, but not the main one.
In this article, you will get in touch with one method to validate user input in the route, before data gets saved, regardless of where you choose to store the data.
In a hurry?
Go straight to the source code on Github:
https://github.com/remix-cookbook/articles-form-validation-with-zod

Starting with a form

children.text: That‚Äôs the right place to introduce the data validation.
Introducing ZOD
ZOD is a library built with Typescript which allows you to describe the data and the format it should be.

https://github.com/colinhacks/zod
Start by installing the library:

$ yarn add zod
// or npm install zod

children.text: And then create the validator and use it to parse user provided data:
So in our particular case, we describe the expected shape and type in the following way:
z.object() - Validator.parse() expects an object;
name: z.string().min(6) - expects a string with minimum 6 characters;
email: z.string().email() - expects a valid e-mail.
The proper way to go about the validation is to pass the received data straight to the method
parse()
of the validator. If the validation passes, the data will be returned. If not, a
ZodError
will be thrown. In such case, we have to wrap our logic within a
try/catch
block.
The 2 possible outputs from the validation process above are:
Note that the returned data upon positive validation is fully typed, thanks to Typescript!

content.alt: Fully typed data returned by validator's parse method

children.text: Based on what is returned by the validation process, we can decide on how to proceed.
Now back to the form, we use the returned data to provide visual feedback to the user:
üí° Note that we are using
key={}
in the form fields. This is a gotcha to force React to re-render the component. Otherwise, your data might not be updated. This happens because when¬†
defaultValue={}
is used, creating an
uncontrolled component
, React will assume that data is immutable and will not re-render the component when the value changes programmatically.
‚ùó
The documentation instructs you to use
Object.fromEntries()
, but it is not recommended for all use cases. Sometimes your form structure is too complex and some data might be lost. To cover most of the cases we recommend you to check out Kiliman's
remix-params-helper
https://github.com/kiliman/remix-params-helper
Conclusion
Does this mean we don‚Äôt need client-side validation?
No!
Does this mean we cannot implement client-side validation?
No!
This means we
must always validate
user input on the server, and we can ‚Äî additionally ‚Äî provide client-side validation for a better user experience. This also falls into progressive enhancement technique.
One last tip is that you can also use ZOD to validate data provided to the React component by the loader function. But this is a subject for a new article.
See you soon!

author: Fabio Vedovelli

children.text: One of the biggest Remix's selling points is progressive enhancement. It is notable you can build your application and delivery it to the browser without shipping any JavaScript. And still, it works as expected.
Of course, one cannot expect great interactive features, but the bare-bones functionality is there.
So, you might be thinking:
‚Äú
If we can build and deliver without JavaScript, why do we need React in the first place.‚Äù
React is a battle-tested-market-validated solution for web development, enabling components and composition. This puts it in a unique position to offer developers solid abstraction capabilities.

Let's take a look at an example. Assume this markup, which contains two links. Their markup and CSS classes are the same and they both open a new window upon click. So, we have an abstraction opportunity here.

content.code:
Our site stats are public and can be accessed on Plausible.io:{' '} https://plausible.io/remix-cookbook.com

Social Media

Follow us on Twitter:{` `} https://twitter.com/RemixCookbook

children.text: We go ahead and create a Link component and include everything that is repeated from the code snippet above. We also include placeholders for the dynamic parts to be provided by the parent component, and then we have a single source of truth for external links.
Going back to the component in which we started, we import and use the new component.

Note that, visually, nothing has changed. But now we have a single place to make improvements. Being a link that will take the user to an external location, it is a common practice to add a small icon on the right-hand side, making it clear a new window will open.

Now both links contain said icon. Imagine we are working in a massive application with hundreds, if not thousands of links, spread throughout the application. One small change and all of them would be updated and ready to ship.
The same is true for any other aspect of the element: colors, spacing, fonts. You name it.
Conclusion

Without React, achieving these results would be very difficult. And because Remix builds everything server-side, you can be pretty confident that even the more expensive computations will not harm your application's performance. The server is a known territory, different from the ‚Äúwild wild‚Äù browser.

title: If Remix delivers HTML and doesn't need JS, why do we need React in the first place?

So we usually get data fetching started from our loader function, which is the very first piece of code that runs when a route is accessed.
At the time of this writing, Remix documentation depicts loader function examples that will not assign any return types for loader functions.
It turns out that if you do not type the return of your loader function, you can't be sure what you're returning is in conformity with what will be accessed in the React component.
Let's leverage Typescript to make our loader function safer:

What is going on there? First, we create an interface to type the response from the loader function. Then we execute the JSON method (provided by Remix), which is a utility to return a Response with JSON encoded data. By passing LoaderData as a type, we ensure only known properties and values could be returned by the loader function.
The code above clearly states everything this method could return or do.
If you remove one of the properties from the returned object, Typescript will let you know immediately!
